duties: Developing a course syllabus, developing course materials (e.g., assignments, tests, exams), teaching a weekly three-hour class (Monday 9-12), conducting office hours, coordinating tutorials with TA assistance, marking assessments.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful applicant will have completed undergraduate and/or graduate courses in biological anthropology. Use of software in course requires competence in basic analytic techniques including database management and descriptive statistics. Candidates must be organized, able to communicate effectively, and work well with undergraduates. Must be available for in person practicals on Mondays at UTM.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates with previous relevant field experience and/or expertise in class topics may be preferred.

application_procedure: Submit cover letter and resume to Carolyn Loos, Department Manager (carolyn.loos@utoronto.ca).
duties: Must be available in person on Wednesday, December 20, 2023 from 8:30am-12:30pm at UTM. As part of a team of assistant invigilators takes directive from ANT204H5F head TA to oversee final exam.
qualifications: Must be available in person on Wednesday, December 20, 2023 from 8:30am-12:30pm at UTM. Successful applicants must be eligible for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work, and have familiarity with ANT204H5 course content. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion. Skills (listed alphabetically): • Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries • Ability to remain calm under pressure • Communication (both oral and written) • Initiative • Interpersonal • Organizational • Problem solving • Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities • Strong computer skills including MS Office (Word, Excel, and Teams) • Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply.

department: Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy (MPP program)
application_procedure: Please send your CV to p.jory@utoronto.ca
duties: Using high-level understanding and fluency with R/ R Studio, provide MPP students with support with cleaning data, providing descriptive statistics, doing empirical analysis (incl: linear regression, difference indifference, regression discontinuity, instrumental variables, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Studies at the MA or PhD level. The ideal candidate has taken undergraduate/ graduate courses in quantitative methods/ statistics and had a solid academic performance so as to adequately support the MPP students. The ideal candidate has experience providing assistance with R/ R Studio.
qualifications_preferred: Providing support with R / R Studio to students. Consulting with students via email, in person and/or online through office hours; Assisting instructor in overall instruction and grading of R / R Studio content ; Experience in working with graduate students; Knowledge of the literature and R / R Studio.

application_procedure: Submit applications on-line to: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/hmb/postings
duties: Duties: • Preparation for, and demonstrating labs • Marking lab reports and posters
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Appropriate background in molecular techniques for the course. A background in physiology, health and fitness would be an asset. Enrolled in a MPH, MSc or PhD program in a science department. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

department: Centre for Industrial Relations & Human Resources
appointment_size: Note: due to a cancellation made since the Oct 23 posting of 70 TA hours, this is now being re-posted at 140 TA hours.  There are other TA hours already assigned.
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to https://www.cirhr.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cirhr-job-postings.   Select the accordion named: "CUPE Unit 1 Opportunities - Undergraduate"  and follow the instructions listed there.
duties:
The position may include: marking tests and/or exams and assignments; holding tutorials; meeting with
students on an individual basis.  TAs are usually required to attend lecture unless they have previous experience with the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Individuals applying for the position should have an academic background which includes completion
of courses in industrial relations or organizational behaviour, and must be a registered student or Postdoctoral Fellow (PDF) at the University of Toronto on the starting date of the appointment and will remain eligible to work in the bargaining unit for the duration of the appointment.
qualifications_preferred: Someone who has completed an undergraduate or graduate level course in this or similar area.

application_procedure: Applicants are required to submit a cover letter, Curriculum Vitae (CV) and draft syllabus as part of the application process. All  materials should be sent by e-mail to Dr. B. Chrubasik, Chair, Department of Historical Studies at hsjobs@utoronto.ca.
duties: Preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades (including any grading or submission of grades not completed by the end of session: December 31, 2023 for the F session and April 30, 2024 for the S); holding regular office hours; supervising TAs (if any) assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful applicants must have advanced training or graduate education in History; be competent in the subject matter of the class; and have organizational and communication skills necessary for the fulfillment of their duties. Applicants with experience in digital humanities are preferred.

application_procedure: All qualified applicants are asked to submit your CV, a sample of history related writing and availability to history.admin@utoronto.ca
duties: MEET with individual undergraduate students to provide constructive feedback on their writing. The advisor is required to provide feedback on structure and to ensure that proper history specific writing requirements are followed. The advisor will be assigned a weekly schedule to meet with undergraduate students
qualifications: Must be current Graduate student enrolled in the Department of History. Qualified applicants must have proven skills in writing and communication. Success in this position requires the ability to mentor undergraduate students in approaches to writing history essays and other history writing assignments, such as primary source analyses.

application_procedure: All qualified applicants are asked to submit your CV, a sample of history related writing and availability to history.admin@utoronto.ca
duties: Provide support to the Writing Advisors. Assist the department with the management of the writing centre.  Meet with individual undergraduate students to provide constructive feedback on their writing. The advisor is required to provide feedback on structure and to ensure that proper history specific writing requirements are followed. The advisor will be assigned a weekly schedule to meet with undergraduate students
qualifications: Must be current Graduate student enrolled in the Department of History. Qualified applicants must have proven skills in writing, communication, mentorship and team leadership. Success in this position requires the ability to mentor undergraduate students in approaches to writing history essays and other history writing assignments, such as primary source analyses as well as team leadership.

job_title: Global Asian Studies: Insights and Concepts
application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a cover letter and updated CV (including previous teaching evaluations if applicable) by December 1, 2023. Letters of recommendation are not required but will be accepted. Applications should be sent via email to Asian Institute Program Administrator and Communications Officer Rebecca Bi at ai.asianstudies@utoronto.ca.  YOU MUST USE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOUR SUBJECT LINE: APPLICATION: COURSE CODE: LAST NAME. Please attach your CV and cover letter as PDFs, and label your attachments as follows: Last Name_First Name_Cover; Last Name_First Name_CV.

To access accommodation during the application and hiring processes, and throughout the duration of the appointment, please contact Rebecca Bi at ai.asianstudies@utoronto.ca.
duties:

Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated interest in Asia-Pacific and/or South Asian Studies and strong performance in a social sciences or humanities graduate program is required.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates with grounded research experience in East, Southeast, and/or South Asian Studies who are excelling in their respective disciplinary graduate program, and those that evince a multi-regional social science perspective that includes critical approaches to area studies, public culture and markets, ethnography and/or historical studies. First consideration will be given to senior PhD students at the University of Toronto, but strong MA students are invited to apply. TA experience is preferred.

duties: Teaching Assistants may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: giving student tutorials or lectures; marking tests and assignments; assisting in making lecture materials and tests available to students (online, electronic or hard copy); administering course evaluation surveys; answering student questions by e-mail; invigilating in-person or online tests and final exams; sending reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; being present on the day of lecture to help with setup (if in-person lectures are allowed); helping lecturers setup online lectures in Zoom or Blackboard Collaborate; maintaining the course Quercus page; preparing online or hard-copy exam packages; contributing to marking mid-term and final exams or coordinating marking of exam questions to lecturers; hosting Q&A sessions for final exam preparation. The selected individual will be a primary TA to the course listed, but will also be a back up secondary TA to one other course in the same term (to be determined).
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Open to current graduate students who have completed at least one year of their program by September 2023. Students should have strong academic qualifications, teaching ability, excellent oral and interpersonal skills, ability to work effectively with course lecturers and students, strong administrative skills, and appropriate background for the course.
qualifications_preferred: Current graduate students in LMP, Biochemistry, Molecular Genetics or Physiology, or those who graduated from the Pathobiology Specialist Program with previous teaching experience are preferred.

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.

job_title: Basic principles of machine learning in biomedical research
application_procedure: Please submit your application via: https://lmp.forms-db.com/view.php?id=465522
duties: Teaching Assistants may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: giving students tutorials or lectures; marking tests and assignments; assisting in making lecture materials and tests available to students; administering course evaluation surveys; available for student questions by e-mail; invigilating tests and final exams; sending reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; be present at the day of lecture to help with setup; maintaining the course Quercus page; preparing exam packages; contributing to marking mid-term and final exams or coordinating marking of exam questions with lectures; hosting Q&A sessions for final exam preparation. Evaluating course presentations, maintaining course website and course materials, designing course material and projects. This course will be delivered in-person.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD student in computer science or in a health science discipline with a strong background in machine learning and its application in biomedical research. Excellent programming skills in Python are required.
qualifications_preferred: Extensive research experience with applying ML in biomedical research is preferred.

application_procedure: For detailed posting information and application procedure, go to: http://uoft.me/fyojobs
duties: The Junior TA duties centre around shadowing the activities of the full TA assigned to the course.  The Junior TA will attend tutorials and follow along with the marking of assessments.  Once they have gained some experience, they will begin to assist with grading assessments and running tutorials.  It is expected that the Junior TA will run at least one tutorial during the semester. Other support for the delivery of the course may be required, as needed
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.This position is intended as a training ground for future full TAs.  Previous experience as a TA is not required and may disqualify an applicant from the position.  We are looking for an applicant who is interested in learning from an experienced TA and hopes to develop into a full TA or other teaching role.
The course is a T-program offering of Calculus, so direct or indirect experience with the struggles of first-year engineering students is an important qualification, as is an understanding of what may work to help such students past their difficulties.

qualifications_preferred: Applicants should have taken ECE552 or equivalent (Computer Architecture) and ECE1755 or equivalent (Parallel Computer Architecture and Programming); Knowledge of parallel architecture and coherence; Experience with parallel programming (pthreads, MPI, etc)

application_procedure:
To apply, please email your CV, teaching evaluations (if available), and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT136S". Please indicate which of the listed times you are availble.

If you've already applied for any Fall 2023- Winter 2024 positions you don't need to include CV and evaluations again unless there are  any changes.
duties:
This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections.  The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.
 
Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

application_procedure:
To apply, please email your CV, teaching evaluations (if available), and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT246S".

If you've already applied for any Fall 2023- Winter 2024 positions you don't need to include CV and evaluations again unless there are  any changes.
duties:
This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.
 
If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.
 
Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

application_procedure: Applications should send the requested documents below to the attention of Prof. Salvatore Bancheri, Interim Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2. Cover letter (this should include a statement on the applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3. Current academic CV.
duties: Assist course instructor with TA management and course administration. Mentor and provide feedback to other TAs. Specific duties will be defined in the Description of Duties and Allocation of Hours form. Duties may require travel to the UTM campus. This is a HEAD TA position. Note: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated background and training in the specific themes of the course (social and cultural issues in education) is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in teacher education is preferred. Experience applying theory and research in a classroom environment is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.

application_procedure:

1. Cover Letter 
2. Curriculum Vitae or Resume

duties:
Teaching assistants will prepare motivating and stimulating materials that engage students in dynamic and interactive learning during practicums, provide constructive feedback and encourage confidence-building participation that develops students' competence in academic oral and written communication. The special focus on rapid expansion of core vocabulary and academic writing provides the foundation and practical experience for students to cope effectively with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations. Students will engage actively in collaborative peer learning through consistent engagement with cell group interactions, Peer Scholar interactions, assigned group work outside class as well as through online learning. 

Responsible for leading one in-person practicum session per week on Wednesdays, 12 noon - 1 pm in a way that establishes a robust highly-interactive learning community both online and in the physical class; conduct office hours; grade projects, assignments, oral presentations and reflective journals; mid-terms and final assessments; facilitate the discussion board to stimulate an active and genuine exchange of ideas and deepening of critical thinking skills; grade quality of participation in discussion board and Peer Scholar; responsible for conducting assessments in accordance with criteria specified; provide supportive written feedback and guidance that helps individual students to develop their vocabulary and increase critical thinking and academic writing skills. 

Appointment Dates: January 2, 2024 to April 30, 2024
Practicum Dates: January 17, 2024 - March 27, 2024
Practicum Times: Wednesdays, 12:00-1:00pm (In-person)
Office Hours: To be arranged
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A minimum Master's degree in a relevant field; a minimum of 3 years of experience teaching at a university; evidence of ability to support the development of critical thinking and academic communication skills (especially academic writing) of multilingual university students who have significant needs related to English for Academic Purposes; relevant experience teaching writing one-on-one and/or teaching in university courses with a significant writing instruction component; having both kinds of experience would be a strong advantage; demonstrated ability and high level of comfort discussing and teaching grammar to students in university courses; excellent communication and motivational skills, and demonstrated ability to be perceived as highly approachable by students; demonstrated ability to create a lively, highly motivating learning environment and sustain students' interest in learning (as reflected through student attendance and engagement throughout the semester).
qualifications_preferred: Experience supporting student learning through an online environment; training in education or applied linguistics would be a great asset; experience working with a diverse group of students and training in second-language instruction at the university level; demonstrated evidence of active involvement in research in the field of second language writing; experience with teaching that involves critical Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy with specified use of Generative AI in achieving course goals;  a demonstrated ability and experience using Canvas (Quercus). Knowledge and experience using web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom.
salery: January 1, 2023: UG/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $47.64 per hour + 4% vacation pay

application_procedure: Applications should submit their applications by email to Ab Atre. Cover letter and resume should be submitted as ONE document. Along with a CI application form https://moleculargenetics.utoronto.ca/teaching-assistantships-ta
duties:
This is a laboratory course designed to introduce third and fourth year undergraduates
to principles and practice of whole-genome sequencing. During the course, student
teams sequence an entire eukaryotic genome and analyze it. Topics taught include: modern
sequencing technology, yeast husbandry, genomic library construction and quality control,
‘next-generation’ sequencing, sequence assembly using a reference genome, principles of
genome organization, mutation detection and interpretation. The work includes both “wet”
lab components during the first half of the course and computational analysis (online) for
the last few weeks of the course.

The course is structured as a weekly three-hour laboratory session each Tuesday from 1-4 pm
throughout the winter semester. Most sessions will be approximately one hour of
lecture/discussion led by the instructor and two hours of hands on lab work. Some lab sessions
will go a bit longer. The instructor is expected to attend all lab sessions, help prepare the lab
beforehand, and to answer student questions. The approximate time commitment is 8 hours per
week. Some interactions with students are expected to be done online this year.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
The applicant should be experienced with concepts and methods in next-generation sequencing
and the analysis of genome scale sequence data. The applicant should also be knowledgeable
with basic yeast biology and yeast husbandry. Previous teaching experience is desirable but not
required
ta_support: 2 TA will be helping with the course

duties: The Computing for Medicine program is a program run by the Department of Computer Science and the Faculty of Medicine. The program is designed to introduce medical students to programming and to the applications of computing to medicine. Students will participate in a series of bootcamp-style workshops where they will learn to program in Python and in seminars with a corresponding project on the application of computing to medicine. The course culminates in submission of a project targeting prediction of clinical outcomes in real data.

Experience with applying computer science in a practical setting and broad knowledge of computer science fundamentals.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/hash/public/postings/rcLQ5QjmHQTU4ete2UxSdmDQ ; For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu
duties:
Attend in-person lectures to assist in classroom activities; only 1 of 7 sections will be carried out with dual delivery (both in person and remotely). Prepare for each week by doing online or possibly in-person programming activities. Hold office hours, predominately in-person on-campus. Mark tests and exams. May include other tasks, such as monitoring discussion forums. Most TA work will involve participation in person (including weekly TA meetings and marking sessions.) TA work done remotely will require a computer on which software such as Python can be installed on (a tablet computer such as a Chromebook or iPad is likely NOT sufficient) and a reliable  high-speed internet connection. For any remote office hours, TAs must be willing and able to participate with their cameras on.  TAs should have some availability Monday to Friday, 9am to 6pm for in-person office hours. There is limited availablilty to conduct office hours in the evening period. TAs must be available for 6 hours of in-person midterm marking around Reading Week. 

This course also requires all TAs to be available to mark the final exam in-person.  Every effort will be made to schedule the exam marking within 5-7 business days after the final exam date.  There is a small chance TAs may be required to work past April 30 if the exam is scheduled the last week of April.  The exam schedule is released in March 2024. All times given are Toronto time.


TAs should be available during at least one full set of the CSC108 lecture times.

L0101: M9–11 and W10-11      
L0201/L0202/L0203: M13-15 and W13-14     
L0301: TU13-15 and TH13-14           
L0401: TU15-17 and TH15-16         
Hybrid: one section only: L5101: M18-20 and W18-19.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/hash/public/postings/rcLQ5QjmHQTU4ete2UxSdmDQ ; For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu
duties:
Classroom TAs will be assigned  one of the two lecture sections of CSC111 (see Arts & Science timetable for section times). For their assigned lecture, TAs will attend lecture in-person and assist with active learning and moderating and participating in an online chat; they may also assist with preparation of lecture materials. Other responsibilities may include: holding office hours; answering questions on the online discussion forum; assisting with assessment preparation and proofreading; grading student work, including assignments, tests and the final exam.

This course also requires all TAs to be available to mark the final exam together online-sychronously or in-person. Every effort will be made to schedule the exam marking within 5-7 business days after the final exam date. All TAs must have access to a computer and a reliable high-speed Internet connection to complete assigned work. TAs must be able to install course software such as Python; a tablet computer such as a Chromebook or iPad is NOT sufficient. TAs must be available for in-person course team meetings during regular business hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

duties: Course Summary: Strategic management, as taught in this course, is about why some businesses are able to consistently turn a profit, while others are not. The course identifies sources beyond “luck” that explain why firms with the same opportunities can nonetheless perform so differently.  Among other topics, the course explores: 1. Why certain strategic choices fit together better than others. 2. How industries shape firm performance. 3. The strategies firms pursue to create and capture value. 4. When firms should grow, shrink, or expand in scope. 5. How firms pursue innovation. 6. How firms motivate workers, managers, and suppliers. Throughout the semester students will read a combination of academic papers, practitioner articles, and case studies, exploring these themes and topics. The ultimate goal of the course is to improve students' decision-making and critical thinking capabilities through learning and applying strategy tools and through active discussion and debate with peers. The emphasis of the course, and particularly of class discussion, is on rigorous thinking and learning rather than finding the “right” answer. The course is designed to function like an MBA course and emphasizes class participation, class discussion, and professionalism. Position Description: All normal duties related to the design, administration and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content following the course template used by other instructors; supervision of teaching assistants; development, administration and marking of class participation, assignments, tests and examinations; calculation and submission of grades to university officials; holding regular student office hours and maintaining reasonable availability for student contact.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Required qualifications are a graduate degree with a specialization in Strategy, Management or Economics.   Preference will be given to those with a PhD in progress or completed in Strategic Management or a closely related discipline.   Also required is recent teaching and professional experience in Strategic Management.  Proven excellence in teaching Strategic Management in a degree granting program at a post-secondary institution is highly preferred.  Short-listed candidates may be interviewed before a hiring decision is made.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to those with a PhD in progress or completed in Strategic Management or a closely related discipline.

duties: IFP050H1S – Reading and Writing in Mathematics  - This course focuses on improving students abilities to read and write mathematics. It is intended to hone your critical thinking skills and prepare you for proof-based courses in the coming years. We will study a variety of topics from pure mathematics in order to gain an understanding of what abstract mathematics is and how it is practiced. Topics include: popular methods of proof, basic concepts in number theory, geometry, logarithms, trigonometry and a brief introduction to calculus. The course will focus on the idea of a proof - a clear piece of writing that follows certain rules of logic to convince its readers. There will be a lot of practice in the writing of proofs in lectures and tutorials, as well as on assignments, quizzes and tests. DUTIES:  Holding office hours to discuss assignments and tests;  Consulting with the instructor; Advising students about and marking course assignments and tests; May be required to attend lectures

qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants engaged in related research and who have a demonstrated understanding of the learning needs of international students who speak English as an additional language.

duties:
NEW349H1S  explores the work of disabled, mad, sick and/or Deaf artists and considers how disability disrupts - or 'crips' - artistic spaces and cultural movements. Engages with contemporary debates emanating from within these spaces and movements to reveal disability as a dynamic range of bodily practices, aesthetics and relations.

Normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and holding regular office hours.

qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience at the university level is preferred.

duties:
CSE270H1S – An introduction to issues and questions arising from the field of 'community engagement'. Explores the meaning, practices and implications of/for 'community' and 'community (dis)engagement' from multiple perspectives (e.g. the State and its agencies, institutional power, colonial discourse, communities of embodied difference, etc.) Takes a multi-media and arts-based approach to examining self-care from an anti-colonial perspective of central importance in the practice and pedagogy of critical equity and solidarity in the collective struggle for freedom and transformation. 

DUTIES: 
Preparing and conducting two weekly tutorials ; Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; may include attending lectures

qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with current theory and practice of community engagement.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants engaged in related research. Teaching experience facilitating small groups is desirable

job_title: Theorizing Settler Colonialism, Capitalism and Race
department: New College - Critical Studies in Equity and Solidarity
application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a letter of application, an updated curriculum vitae, names and contact information (email and phone) for two referees or two reference letters by November 21, 2023. Applications should be sent to New College Program Administrator

 Late or incomplete applications will not be considered.
duties:
CSE341H1S – Provides students with a theoretical background for understanding settler colonialism, capitalist social relations and difference (including race, class, gender, disability and sexuality) and solidarity. Provides an analysis of state violence and the formation of hegemonic power relations. Introduces students to the method of thinking dialectically to examine the social world as a set of relations between multiple phenomena occurring at the same time. Articulates an emancipatory politics of knowledge production and strategies of building solidarities to enable the imagination of a different future.

DUTIES: 
Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; may include attending lectures
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with historical and theoretical foundations of colonialism, racism and/or capitalism, the inequities these social relations produce, and have some background in community organizing.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants engaged in some aspect of equity-related research
salery: SGS I & SGS II Rate = $47.64/hour (+ 4% vacation pay)

duties:
NEW116H1S – What is the role of science in addressing current global threats? What are the possibilities and the limitations of scientific research and knowledge in tackling complex problems such as climate change, pandemics and pollution? In this course, students explore these questions by examining case studies, meeting with specialists in various scientific fields, and engaging in research on a topic of their own choice. 

NEW116H1S are two of ten small interdisciplinary seminars comprising the first year foundational program, New One: Learning without Borders. The courses reflect the program’s defining theme, “learning without borders,” by exploring a locally relevant issue through a transnational lens,  building students’ capacities as critically reflective learners, emphasizing creative pedagogy and interdisciplinarity, engaging the perspectives of community members and senior students; and fostering student development overall.  New One courses meet for 3 hours each week.  A portion of those sessions will occasionally be allocated to “Learning Labs.”  All students in the program come together in these Learning Labs to engage in joint activities and explore issues that are common to the four topics.   Both in seminars and Learning Labs, students will experience a variety of ways of learning (through, for example, guest lectures, group work, workshops, field trips to local community organizations, and panels of senior students sharing their experience and insights).

The salary will be the minimum rates in the collective agreement plus an additional 3% stipend to account for the following duties: Over the course of this appointment, the Sessional Lecturer will be required to attend approximately 10 hours of meetings with the New One Coordinator and Instructors to coordinate assignments, plan plenary sessions and evaluate the program. 

DUTIES:  Planning and teaching the seminar course, grading and giving feedback on assignments, providing office hours for academic counseling of students 

Liaising with the program coordinator and other New One instructors to coordinate and design assignments, plan plenary sessions and evaluate the program.    

Incorporating guest speakers and field trips into the course with administrative support from the program coordinator and assistant.  

Participating in and occasionally leading the activities of the plenary sessions.

duties: Primary responsibilities are to serve as a teaching assistant for a third year pharmacy student mental health and addiction elective course. The position will involve coordinating lecture schedules, booking and confirming guest lecturers, leading and responding to discussion board activity, including the “In the News” assignment, marking assignments, uploading recordings into Quercus.  Additional duties include: meetings with course coordinators (virtually); course orientation; reading text and journal articles relevant to course content and assignments; reviewing assessment guides, drafting and/or providing feedback on assessment questions; invigilating assessments; assist with tabulation of grades; recording and/or delivering a lecture in your field.  The duties will be performed as a mix of in-person and remote tasks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Masters or PhD students with a pharmacy licence and/or background in pharmacy practice; Current U of T graduate students in good standing; Interest in teaching and working with third year pharmacy students; Clinical expertise and experience with mental health and addictions is required.

duties:
“- Delivering the lectures in-person as scheduled.
- Maintaining course administration including: course website on quercus, marking schemes, lectures, tutorials, assignments, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Managing the grades and submitting final course grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term
- Invigilating the final exam if applicable. 
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam); 
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"- BSc in computer science or related field
- completed or working towards a graduate degree in computer science or a related field preferred
- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course
- strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills
- previous experience as a course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset
- demonstrated evidence of excellence in Teaching an asset
qualifications_preferred: see minimum qualifications

duties:
BPM335H1S – In recent years, the effects of meditation on the body have been widely researched.  There is an increasing body of evidence that mindfulness meditation can affect brain activity, brain structure, neurochemistry and other psychobiological process (e.g. blood pressure, cardiac function).  This course will examine the research in this emerging field. DUTIES: 
Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; may include attending lectures

qualifications_preferred:
Prior work or study concentrated on the same concepts and issues covered in the dedicated ARM concentration MI program at UofT’s Faculty of Information (including MI level or less traditional academic learning environments that would have given the candidate exposure to the work and challenges that arise when pursuing organizational or community-centered archives and records management requirements and solutions). 

Demonstrated knowledge of active records management policy and procedural frameworks including file classification, retention and disposition scheduling, digital preservation requirements, and information and data management planning. 

Demonstrated knowledge and or practice with risk and change management techniques.

Desire to present/share with the class their PhD research in the following areas (or similar): Organizational data/Information sovereignty, Community archiving initiatives, Data, information, or records management theory and practice, Information culture.

Preference for candidates who bring diverse perspectives from their lived experiences whose participation as TA in this course may contribute to greater equity in the archives and information management community of practice.

application_procedure: Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. Please include a cover letter on describing why you would be interested in being involved with this outreach event celebrating women and gender minorities in statistics and data science. Please link to your GitHub profile and highlight relevant experience from your CV. The deadline to submit your application is November 17, 2023. For more information, you may contact:Angela Niazmand700 University Avenue, Room 9160-6 Toronto, Ontario, M5G 1Z5 www.statistics.utoronto.caE-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
As part of a joint event with CANSSI Ontario, the Department of Statistical Sciences will be hosting an outreach event for high school students on Saturday, March 2, 2024. This event celebrates women and gender minorities in statistics and data science. The TAs for this position will perform the following duties:
•Work through asynchronous training materials in preparation for the event•Run activities for the high school students to participate in on March 2, 2024•Communicate with high school students, other TAs, faculty and industry mentors who attend the eventThis event is in-person and all TAs must be able to attend in person.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: •Must have previous experience using R and R studio for data analysis and data visualizations, including tools likeggplot•Must have previous experience writing reports and communicating analysis results in non-academic language•Have previously taken or are currently taking STA304 or equivalent in survey design and ethics•Strong oral and written communication skills both for academic and non-academic audiences•Excellent interpersonal skills and the ability to work effectively in a team•Experience and current knowledge of second year level statistics courses and concepts including regressionanalysis•Previous experience leading workshops or small learning groups is preferred•A successful candidate is passionate in statistics outreach and in engaging with non-statistics and novice-levelstudents in statistics education and communication. The ability to communicate and engage with others. We strongly encourage applications from students in undergraduate DoSS programs who are from historically underrepresented groups in Statistics and Data Science.Applicants must be available to attend and work the event in-person at the UofT STG campus on March 2, 2024.
qualifications_preferred: •Previous experience leading workshops or small learning groups is preferred

duties: Course Description: This is an introductory course in corporate finance that provides a framework for analyzing the major types of investment and financial decisions made by corporations. Lectures and readings will provide an introduction to: capital budgeting principles and the cost of capital; capital structure and dividend decisions; the valuation of firms for mergers and acquisitions; corporate governance systems; working capital management; and the use of options for risk control. Position Description: All normal duties related to the design, administration and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; supervision of teaching assistants; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and examinations; calculation and submission of grades to university officials; holding regular student office hours and maintaining reasonable availability for student contact.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: none
qualifications_preferred: Required qualifications are an undergraduate and/or graduate degree with a specialization in Finance or related discipline. Preference will be given to those with a PhD in progress or completed in Finance or a closely related discipline. Recent experience teaching or assisting Corporate Finance or closely related course in a degree granting program at a post secondary institution highly preferred. Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

job_title: Applications of Machine Learning in Finance
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to  http://www-2.rotman.utoronto.ca/employment/tapositions/
duties:
Course Description: This course introduces students to the tools of machine learning with emphasis on their applications in finance. Students will learn enough about machine learning techniques to work productively with data science specialists. The course will cover the main techniques used by data scientists to handle large data sets for prediction, clustering, and interacting with a changing environment.  Students are not expected to become programming experts but will gain familiarity with Python. This language is widely used in the finance sector and is particularly useful for handling large data sets. 

Position Description: All normal duties related to the design, administration and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; supervision of teaching assistants; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and examinations; calculation and submission of grades to university officials; holding regular student office hours and maintaining reasonable availability for student contact.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: none
qualifications_preferred: Required qualifications: The instructor should have expertise in machine learning and have teaching experience related to both machine learning and finance.  Recent experience teaching machine learning to business students in a degree granting program at a post secondary institution highly preferred.  A PhD in a related field is preferred. Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

Further details about the Department’s hiring policy are available in the Department office and in the CUPE, Local 3902 office.

job_title: From Genomes to Ecosystems in a Changing World (labs)
application_procedure: Applications are to be submitted online, https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/eeb/login, logging in with existing UTORid and password (select Applications, then Fall-Winter 2023-24 - Winter). If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact the EEB Graduate Office
duties: Demonstrate labs (16-20 students per section); grade assignments; invigilate tests; plus 5 hours paid training
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
An academic background in ecology and/or evolutionary biology is required. EHS601 Laboratory Biosafety Training is a required pre-requisite and certification must be valid for the duration of this TAship (https://ehs.utoronto.ca/our-services/biosafety/biosafety-training/); EHS601 must be taken once and then the Biosafety refresher course (EHS602) must be taken annually after that. 
WHMIS and Lab Safety Training is a required pre-requisite and certification must be valid for the duration of this TAship: WHMIS and Lab Safety (EHS101) must be taken once and then the WHMIS Refresher (EHS112) must be taken annually after that: https://ehs.utoronto.ca/our-services/chemical-and-lab-safety/whmis/whmis-lab-safety-training/
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience teaching this course or similar introductory biology course is preferred.

job_title: Environmental Biology: From Organisms to Ecosystems
application_procedure: Applications are to be submitted online, https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/eeb/login, logging in with existing UTORid and password (select Applications, then Fall-Winter 2023-24 - Winter). job_title: Data Analytics with Financial Accounting Information
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to  http://www-2.rotman.utoronto.ca/employment/tapositions/
duties: "Course Summary: This course introduces the analytical mindset and data analytics skills that accounting professionals need to analyze and evaluate a variety of data in order to create insights for making decisions. In particular, you will learn to ask the right questions, prepare the relevant data, apply the appropriate data analytics methods, and interpret the results to answer the questions. You will also learn to use common data analytics tools, such as Excel, Access (SQL), and Tableau to prepare, analyze, and model financial data. Finally, you will apply the analytical mindset and data analytics skills to address various accounting, finance, and general business problems."
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: An advanced graduate degree is required with a specialization in Accounting; candidates should ether have a PhD or have made substantial progress towards getting their PhD. Candidates should have strong technical skills and knowledge of accounting, economics, statistics and econometrics. Candidates should also have mastery over data modeling and data analytics and familiarity with he use of Excel, Access and Tableau for these applications. Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: NA

application_procedure:
Applicants should submit (1) a current curriculum vitae, (2) a one-page outline of what you would propose for the course, and (3) evidence of teaching ability (e.g., summarized course evaluations, letters of reference, etc.).  A description of courses is available at https://fas.calendar.utoronto.ca/ 

Applications should be addressed to Professor Srilata Raman. Please send your application as a single PDF file to religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca. Course evaluations should be sent as a separate PDF file. The subject line of the email should read Unit 1 Application: [course code].
duties: Presenting weekly lectures and classes as appropriate, grading papers and exams, meeting with students individually as they request, and handling the other pedagogical and administrative tasks ordinarily associated with an undergraduate course.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD candidacy in the Department for the Study of Religion or a completed PhD in religion or a related field. Ability to addres the themes of the course to which the application is being made.
qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated teaching experience as a teaching assistant, teaching fellow, or course instructor; extensive knowledge of the subject area is highly desirable.

duties: Collaborating with the course coordinator to develop, deliver and administer a series of 11 hours of lectures on ion channel function and pharmacology. Hosting office hours to discuss the lecture material and answer any questions. Prepare a mid-term examination and final examination for students which may consist of a mixture of multiple-choice and short and long answer questions. Coordinate the marking of the examination and report the marks on Quercus and to the course coordinator. Prepare a make-up or supplementary examination as needed for any students. Interact with information technology staff to obtain instruction and guidance on online teaching using the Quercus platform, and to resolve any issues with online delivery of course material or assessments. Interacting with teaching assistants in the course as needed to facilitate delivery of course material or to coordinate assessments and marking as required
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: B.Sc. in pharmacology, physiology, or other related discipline.
qualifications_preferred: M.Sc. in Pharmacology, physiology, or related discipline. Research experience in the study of ion channel function and/or electrophysiology. Prior teaching experience is an asset.

application_procedure:
Only formal applications will be entertained. A SEPARATE application package is required for each course applied to. The application package for EACH course must include a single file in PDF format, containing the following in order:
1) Completed application form available online here: https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/management/media/377/download?inline
2) Current Curriculum Vitae (including valid e-mail address).
Submit completed application by email to: jobs.utmm@utoronto.ca
PDF File Format Name: “LastName, FirstName_Course Code”
Email Subject: “LastName, FirstName_Course Code”
duties: The duties of Course Instructors shall include the normal duties associated with the design and teaching of university degree credit courses or sections of courses. These include the preparation and delivery of course content, including lectures and/or seminars; creation of course ware; the development/administration of assignments, tests and examinations; the marking/grading of student work and the submission of grades to appropriate University officials in accordance with policy; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours; and the supervision of the day-to-day work of any Sessional Instructional Assistants or Teaching Assistants assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Course Instructors are expected to be of superior teaching ability, with suitable academic and/or professional qualifications, currency and mastery of the subject matter. Successful applicants will have clearly demonstrated teaching excellence in the subject matter through previous experience teaching the course in question, or very similar courses.
qualifications_preferred: Successful applicants will typically have significant experience in applying the subject matter in a practical environment.
salery:
Course Instructor: $8,142.51 (0.5 FCE)
Course Instructor (first CI appointment): $9,123.38 (0.5 FCE)

department: Centre for Industrial Relations & Human Resources
appointment_size: 70 (there are other TA hours already assigned)
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to https://www.cirhr.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cirhr-job-postings.   Select the accordion named: "CUPE Unit 1 Opportunities - Undergraduate"  and follow the instructions listed there.
duties:
The position may include: marking tests and/or exams and assignments; holding tutorials; meeting with
students on an individual basis.  TAs are usually required to attend lecture unless they have previous experience with the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Individuals applying for the position should have an academic background which includes completion
of courses in industrial relations or organizational behaviour, and must be a registered student or Postdoctoral Fellow (PDF) at the University of Toronto on the starting date of the appointment and will remain eligible to work in the bargaining unit for the duration of the appointment.
qualifications_preferred: Someone who has completed an undergraduate or graduate level course in this or similar area.

duties: Primary responsibilities are to serve as teaching assistant for pharmacy students in health and physical assessment, and injection techniques. Will be available for in-person, on campus duties on Wednesdays in Winter term. Additional duties include: meetings with supervisor; Course orientation; Reading text and journal articles relevant to course content and assignments; reviewing lab facilitation guides, providing assessment and feedback on course activities, marking assignments.  Meeting and provide support with students during TA & requested hours; Invigilating assessments; assist with tabulation of grades; Attending learning settings as negotiated with supervisor; Session preparation including preparation of supplies, rooms, as requested.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Masters of Nursing, Nurse Practitioner, or PhD students (Nursing); Current U of T graduate students in good standing; Interest in teaching and working with novice pharmacy students; Clinical expertise and experience with physical assessment and injection techniques.

duties: Marking assignments, invigilation mid-term tests and exam. Assist students with problems in accounting  Conduct weekly one hour tutorials mostly held on Friday.  Must be able to provide assistance on financial and managerial accounting related questions during TA office hours.  All duties to be completed at UTSC or online.

qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student within the Management programme. Excellent understanding of financial accounting as demonstrated by an excellent grade in MGAB01H3/MGAB02H3 (MGTB05/06) and MGAC01H3/MGAC02H3 (MGTC07/08) or equivalent. Ability to communicate well in writing and orally for accounting aid centre.  Excellent knowledge of introductory financial and managerial accounting materials is required.  Excellent understanding of case analysis is a must.
qualifications_preferred: Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student within the Management programme. Excellent understanding of financial accounting as demonstrated by an excellent grade in MGAB01H3/MGAB02H3 (MGTB05/06) and MGAC01H3/MGAC02H3 (MGTC07/08) or equivalent. Excellent understanding of case analysis is a must.

duties: Assist students with recording projects as the recording engineer; prepare and teach 1 lecture on video and audio editing. Candidate will serve as the recording engineer for approximately 20 students, who will each get a 45-minute session for a demo creation assignment in the course. The assignment guidelines limit the recorded repertoire and ensembles to no more than 4 students in a group, and do not allow complicated overdubbing, multi-tracking, or other more extensive recording effects. Recording sessions will be scheduled in blocks of generally 4 back-to-back students (~3 hours total each time), likely in the mornings or evenings in the first half of the winter term in the Edward Johnson Building. It is anticipated that we will be able to use audio equipment from the Music & Technology area that will need to be set up and taken down before/after each recording session, and a video camera from the Music Library.  The course students will be responsible for editing their audio and video takes, not the TA. To empower them to do this, the candidate will also present one 50-minute in-class lecture around the third week of the term, taking the students through step-by-step procedures to accomplish both the basic audio and video editing. The course meets Mondays 1:10-2pm at the Edward Johnson Building.  A lecture template using Reaper and OpenShot is available for the TA to review and modify if needed; if the TA wishes to create a new lecture template, it must be sent to the course instructor ahead of the presentation.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated knowledge and skill in the subject area.
qualifications_preferred: Experience with basic audio and video recording of voices and instruments in classical, jazz, and pop/world genres preferred.

job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness (Adult)
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/join-the-faculty/clinical-instructor-positions/#content6
duties: The Lawrence S. Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students' knowledge, skill, and judgement. CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                  Duties and Responsibilities:                  1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR460.          2. Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.  3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 4. Prepare patient assignments prior to the students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.                                5. Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic and therapeutic concepts.                   6. Encourage an inquiring, theory and evidence-based approach to nursing practice.                                    7. Facilitate interprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team                                   8. Supervise and monitor student progress and safety when performing therapeutic practice skills such as medication administration, wound care and IV administration.        9. Collaborate with nursing staff in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.                                10. Foster discussion and debate about clinical learning among students during post conferences.      11. Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 12. Complete and submit an online written final evaluation of each student that highlights students' learning and progress with meeting the clincal practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (acute care nursing).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/join-the-faculty/clinical-instructor-positions/#content6
duties: The Lawrence S. Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. CIs are expected to support both students and preceptors in placements. CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                Duties and Responsibilities:                  1.  Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR461.                                2. Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site as required.  3. Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g. CI and student absences, Professional Behaviours).  4. Assist students in creating clinical learning objectives for their respective community placements that are reflective of course outcomes, clinical practice expectations and students’ level of learning.                     5. Assist in the delivery of a three-hour primary skills lab for students, in collaboration with faculty (date/time to be confirmed)      6. Collaborate with the NUR461 course instructors to plan the weekly virtual clinical discussion sessions in alignment with the course theoretical concepts.                                      7. Prepare for and facilitate a weekly online, synchronous two-hour clinical discussion with the students, reflecting on virtual case scenarios completed by the students and building on existing clinical experiences.    8. Monitor student performance and assess student progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course.  9.  Ensure ongoing communication with students, preceptors and course faculty.                                                       10. Collaborate with course faculty throughout the term as needed to deal with student clinical placement issues.    11.  Complete and submit an online written final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights students’ learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Excellent understanding of primary health care principles and the social determinants of health. 
2. Professional nursing experience in public health and community health, including rural and/or underserved settings.
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. Current membership in the Registered Nurses Association of Ontario (RNAO) is preferred. 
5. Master's degree in Nursing or equivalent is preferred; BScN is required. 
6. Previous teaching experience will be considered an asset.                                                                                                                7. Excellent facilitation, analytical, and written and oral communication skills.                                                                                                                 8. Competent in MS Office applications.                             9. Experience using online Learning Management Systems.
Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”
