job_title: Introduction to Nursing Care of Childbearing Persons and Families
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/join-the-faculty/clinical-instructor-positions/#content6
duties:
The Lawrence S. Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 

CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.  

Duties and Responsibilities:
1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR374. 
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of course outcomes, clinical practice expectations and students' level of learning.
5.	Actively facilitate students’ application of theory related to trauma informed care, foundational nursing skills, interventions, and medication administration practices at a novice level safely and competently 
6.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, therapeutic, and relational concepts.
7.	Encourage an inquiring, theoretical, ethical, and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
8.	Emphasize and demonstrate the importance of family centered care in nursing practice.
9.	Facilitate interprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
10.	Supervise and monitor student progress and safety when assessing, planning, delivering, and evaluating the nursing care they are providing to childbearing persons and their families. 
11.	Collaborate with nursing staff in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
12.	Foster reflection and critical discussion about clinical learning among students during post conferences.
13.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
14.	Complete and submit an online written final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights students’ learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
15.	Arrange and facilitate a 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (post-partum and/or labour and delivery nursing). 
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.  

Duties and Responsibilities:
1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as require and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR373. 
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour).  
4.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise and clinical practice expectations.
5.	Actively facilitate students’ application of theory related to foundational therapeutic (e.g., health assessment, various nursing interventions) and relational skills (e.g., therapeutic relationships).
6.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic and therapeutic concepts.
7.	Encourage an inquiring, theory and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
8.	Emphasize and demonstrate the importance of family centered and developmentally appropriate care in nursing practice.
9.	Facilitate interprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
10.	Supervise and monitor student progress and safety when performing therapeutic practice skills.
11.	Collaborate with nursing staff in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
12.	Foster reflection and critical discussion about clinical learning among students during post conferences.
13.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
14.	Complete and submit an online written final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights students’ learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement. 
15.	Arrange and facilitate a 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (pediatric acute care nursing). 
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: Submit cover letter and resume to p.jory@utoronto.ca
duties: As part of a team of assistant invigilators takes directive from PPG1002H instructor to oversee final exam.
qualifications:
Must be avaialble in person on Dec. 8 from 9.30am-12pm. Successful applicants must be eligible for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work, and have sound understanding of PPG1002H course content. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion. Skills (listed alphabetically): • Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries • Ability to remain calm under pressure • Communication (both oral and written) • Initiative • Interpersonal • Organizational • Problem solving • Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities • Strong computer skills including MS Office (Word, Excel, and Teams) • Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation.
Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply.

Duties include (but are not limited to):  conducting weekly tutorial sections assigned by the instructor; supporting students in the tutorials during regularly assigned office hours; answering student's email inquiries in an appropriate and timely fashion for students in the assigned tutorial section(s), marking all work (essays, assignments, tests, and final exams) by students in the assigned tutorial sections and recording the resulting grades on Quercus; doing all course readings, participating in training for conducting tutorials; and any other relatable duties assigned by the course instructor. Additional duties may include attending lectures and invigilating tests where applicable.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Knowledge in the subject area; minimum MA in Sociology or related discipline, or currently accepted or enrolled in the graduate Sociology program; ability to instruct in writing; strong written and oral communication skills; working knowledge of basic statistics & SPSS preferred.  Must be available to conduct tutorials on THURSDAYS.
qualifications_preferred: History of strong academic success; having taken this course or a similar course; demonstrated proficiency in the subject area of the course.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties include:

-Conduct weekly tutorials in support of lectures
-Revise all tutorial questions and solutions prior to tutorial sessions sessions
-Assist students during tutorial periods
-Must treat the students with respect and answer their questions clearly and concisely
-Grade Quizzes and publish them in Quercus
-Invigilate, grade midterm test and final  
-Must communicate the tutorial requirements clearly to students
-Must not encourage students to skip tutorial periods
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required Qualifications for Tutorials TAs
-A graduate degree from a recognised mechanical engineering program or equivalent_
-Must have a solid foundation in Mechanics in general and Solid Mechanics in particular
-Must possess excellent communications and floor skills
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties of Labs (Practical) TAs include:
-Conduct experiments in support of lectures
-Prepare all lab requirements prior to lab sessions
-Assist students during their labs
-Must ensure students' safety and the integrity of the test rig
-Must treat the students with respect and answer their questions clearly 
-Must check the outcome of the lab by end of each lab
-Grade reports and publish lab marks in Quercus
-Invigilate, grade midterm test and final  
-Must communicate the requirements clearly to students
-Must attend safety course offered by MIE
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required Qualifications for Labs (Practical) TAs
-A graduate degree from a recognised mechanical engineering program or equivalent
-Must have a strong background in experimental mechanics
-Must have a solid foundation in Mechanics in general and Solid Mechanics in particular
-Must possess excellent communications and floor skills
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties include:

Duties of Finite Element Labs TAs
-Conduct structural finite element simulations in support of lectures
-Prepare all finite element lab requirements prior to lab sessions
-Use ANSYS Work Bench to demonstrate its application in design
-Assist students during their finite element labs
-Must treat the students with respect and answer their questions 
-Must check the outcome of the finite element  lab by end of each lab
-Grade finite element project reports and publish lab marks in Quercus
-Invigilate, grade midterm test and final  
-Must communicate the project requirements clearly to students
-Must attend safety course offered by MIE
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required Qualifications for Lab TAs
-A graduate degree from a recognized mechanical engineering program or equivalent
-Must have a strong background in computational mechanics
-Must have a solid foundation in finite element in general and Solid Mechanics in particular
-Must possess excellent communications and floor skills
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties: Maintain and grade assignments including provision of individualized feedback, assist students in office hours, and teach tutorials/labs on theories and technologies related to Data Science including Python programming, data cleaning and analysis, visualization, fundamental machine learning, processing of geographical, temporal, natural language and social network data, fairness and bias analysis.  TAs will grade labs and assignments and participate in exam grading.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Evidence of strong Python coding skills, proficiency with github, knowledge of machine learning and Python toolkits (scipy, numpy, pandas, nltk, sklearn libraries), evidence of substantial experience in the Data Science field.
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge of social network analysis and geographical Python libraries.  Previous employment in a Data Science position.
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca

When required, help with grading and feedback provision, and running tutorials/labs.  TAs will grade labs and assignments and participate in exam grading.

Evidence of interpersonal skills and previous team/group management experience.
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge of social network analysis and geographical Python libraries.  Previous employment in a Data Science position.
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
The duties include:

1) Guiding and coordinating other TAs.
2) Updating project descriptions and associated rubrics 
3) Helping improve the design of tutorial materials
4) Helping the IE instructor coordinate with the three CIs that are also a part of this course
5) Reviewing exam questions that are developed by the instructor
6) Monitoring online discussion forums for student questions
7) Helping the IE instructor collect CEAB data
8) Helping in the contact and scheduling of guest lecturers
9) Delivering a limited number of lectures (approximately 3)"
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: This is a head TA position. It is intended for an experienced TA, who also has significant research experience in the Human Factors domain. The position is not appropriate for Masters students, who have not TA'ed this course before.
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
"The duties are as follows:

1) hold weekly tutorials. The focus of the tutorials is on design. In particular, these TAs should be competent in task analysis, prototyping, and usability studies.

2) develop project assignment instructions (there are three, one for each TA: task analysis, prototyping, and usability testing).

3) grade the projects, enter marks on Portal

4) grade student presentations

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
MIE311 is an elective course for 3rd year Mechanical Engineering students. The course builds upon the pre-requisite thermodynamics course, and focuses on cycles and applications. Topics include: Otto cycle, diesel cycle, Brayton cycle, Rankine cycle, cogeneration, vapour compression and absorption refrigeration, heat pump systems.

TA DUTIES INCLUDE:

- Supervision of heat engines laboratories (default in person, with online as required by instructor)
- Demonstration of laboratory equipment (default in person, with online as required by instructor)
- Updating lab manual
- Composing lab report questions
- Grading of formal lab reports
- Composing assignment questions
- Grading assignments & exams
- Preparing and solving problem sets and draft exams
- Midterm invigilation
- Grading midterm exam questions
- Updating grades spreadsheet and course website
- Additional administrative support, meetings with instructor, and other duties as required
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicant must have taken MIE 411/311/303 or equivalent previously (application should provide year/term MIE 411/311/303 was taken; if equivalent course, please provide course description)

REQUIREMENTS:
1. A large portion of the TA duties include leading experiments within the heat engines lab (MC120), including experiments, such as the IC engine, air compression, diesel engine, and gas turbine. Prior successful experience in the heat engines lab (as a TA or a student) would be an asset.
2. TAs must be available to supervise laboratories in person as well as online. Previous experiences leading tutorials, coaching sports teams, summer camps, etc. would be valuable experiences that would help you lead engaging labs.
3. Outstanding written and oral English communication is an essential requirement for all of these duties. Applicants must demonstrate strong evidence of their communication skills.
4. TAs must be available the entire term in person for administrative meetings, discussion of course materials, etc.
5. TAs must have the ability to move duties online.

INSTRUCTIONS: In addition to the online application, please submit the following via email to Prof. Aimy Bazylak:

1) a cover letter addressed to Prof. Aimy Bazylak (aimy.bazylak@utoronto.ca) that makes a compelling and concise case for being selected as a TA for this course. (1 page max).
2) 1-page CV that highlights your teaching experience,
3) A 2 min (max) pre-recorded mini-lecture (video) to introduce the IC Engine Lab to students at the beginning of the lab (see attached IC Engine lab manual).
4) An example of your technical writing for which you were the sole author and editor.

All items should be combined into a single PDF file, with the filename labelled as FirstName-LastName-MIE311-2024-TA-Applicant-DD-MM-2024.PDF, where DD (day) and MM (month) reflect the day of application submission. The subject heading of your email should be ""MIE311-2024 TA Applicant: FirstName Last Name""

As the course instructor, I will rank the applicants, and the MIE administration will make the final decisions.

MIE311 laboratory package:
https://www.mie.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/MIE311_Lab_Manual_Compiled.pdf

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
"Organizational Design is a 4th year IE course that integrates various perspectives of organizational theory, including change, risk and project management, teamwork, and systems design. The course will be highly applied, drawing from industry examples and perspectives. The TAs will be valuable members of the teaching team. The course examines how engineers as managers can create more effective organizations. The Head TA will be charged with assisting the professor to proactively manage the course Quercus, respond to student messages, respond to unexpected issues and barriers, and oversee the three team TAs as tasks are assigned and completed. 

TA duties include: ASSISTING THE PROFESSOR Help construct tests, prepare materials, grade assignments, design lessons (if interested). Understand the objectives and learning goals the professor has set for the students so you can communicate course materials to them; know the professor's expectations of you. GRADING PAPERS OR EXAMS Grade tests, exams, assignments. Understand the course content and be able to follow a student's thinking to interpret answers that might not be complete; develop and hold tutorials for the assignments to help students understand what is required of them; be consistent so your grading is fair and reliable; know your department's grading procedures and policies and work with your course supervisor to develop grading criteria; become familiar with your department's and the University's policies on academic integrity; develop strategies for dealing with unhappy students. Identify critical information from lectures or readings and then elaborate on it to help students understand the material; attend some class lectures or watch videos so you understand what the students need to know; in some cases, be responsible for testing and grading students' work. 

Please email Sharon Ferguson with questions: sharon.ferguson@mail.utoronto.ca
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Successful applicants will meet the following criteria: 

*A team player *Dependable, and detail oriented 
*Strong communication skills *Responsive (on Piazza and Slack) 
*Compassionate to students and excited about teaching and learning 
*Experience taking MIE459 ideal. 
*Current graduate student (MEng, MASc, PhD) in an engineering discipline at U of T *Work experience in industry, management or supervisory role ideal
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Machine Intelligence, Software and Neural Networks
department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database: https://eceta.ece.toronto.edu/. Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in. DEADLINE TO APPLY IS 11:59pm ON NOVEMBER 1, 2023.

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Meera Puvitharan at meera.puvitharan@utoronto.ca.  If you have general TAship questions, please email ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties:
The course is an introduction to machine learning engineering, with a focus on neural networks. The entire process of developing a machine learning solution, from data collection to software development, as well as ethics in machine learning, will be discussed. Practical techniques in machine learning will be covered, including data augmentation and the use of pre-trained networks.
Topics covered will include the fundamentals of neural networks, convolutional neural networks, recurrent neural networks, generative adversarial networks and transformer networks. Students will complete a major hands-on project in machine learning.
The Teaching Assistants (TAs) will teach tutorials, and mark assignments, projects, and tests.  A key part of the course is the student-chosen project, done in groups. TAs will serve as mentors to specific project groups.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred:
Knowledge/Skills required:  Experience in Python, NumPy, and PyTorch.
Experience and knowledge of libraries for computer vision and/or natural language processing and/or deep reinforcement learning.
Experience in machine learning applications is a key asset.

qualifications_preferred:
Firm knowledge of transmission line theory: voltage and current waves, characteristic impedance, reflections from the load and source, transients on the line, Smith’s chart, impedance matching. Fundamentals of electromagnetic theory: Maxwell’s equations, Helmholtz’s theorem, time retarded scalar and vector potentials, gauges, boundary conditions,
electric and magnetic fields wave equations and their solutions in lossless and lossy medium. Plane wave propagation, reflection and transmission at boundaries. Constitutive relations and dispersion. Radiating dipole and waveguides.

qualifications_preferred: Expertise in analog signal processing in both continuous-time and discrete-time; analog signal specifications; the design of analog filters including transfer function approximation using Matlab and implementation using active-RC, transconductance-C, and switched capacitor circuits: phase locked loops; digital to analog and analog to digital converters. application_procedure:

qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Expertise in radio medium, radio communication systems; Link budget: cable losses, propagation loss, antenna gains; Basic concepts of propagation: path loss, multi-path propagation and fading. Raleigh and Rician fading models, Doppler shift, delay spread, coherence time and coherence bandwidth of the channel; Analog modulation schemes and their bandwidths. Digital modulation schemes and their bandwidths and bit rates: BPSK, QPSK, MSK, GMSK. Basic concepts of speech coding. Error correction coding, interleaving, and multiple access frame structure; the physical layer description of the AMPS, IS-54, and GSM cellular systems. The cellular concept: frequency re-use, re-use cluster concept. Channel allocation. Cellular system architecture for AMPS, IS-54, and GSM. Hand-offs and transmitter power control. Cellular traffic, call blocking, concept of Erlangs. Basic ideas in spread spectrum modulation, spreading codes, bit error probability. Orthogonal and non-orthogonal CDMA Basic concepts in CDMA networks. Prerequisite: ECE302H1 and ECE316H1, or STA286H1

job_title: Special Topics in Computer Hardware Design: Hardware-Accelerated Digital Systems
department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database: https://eceta.ece.toronto.edu/. Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in. DEADLINE TO APPLY IS 11:59pm ON NOVEMBER 1, 2023.

duties: Duties may include conducting tutorials /laboratory demonstrations and marking tutorial/laboratory work, problem sets, tests and examinations.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred:
The instructor is seeking Teaching Assistant(s) to help him with this course. A qualified TA would be someone with work ethics and who has strong hands-on skills, such as high-level software development/debugging as well as digital system design and verification. Familiarity with HW acceleration and optimization of ML systems as well as ways to interface with HW IP’s through API’s is a plus. The number of students attending this class is capped to 16, who will be working on their assignments in groups of 4 students. The following are some tasks that are expected from the TA of this course:
•	In coordination with the lab manager, make sure that the designated lab has all hardware and software that is necessary for the assignments
•	Help the instructor with the assignment(s) preparation in an iterative process through constant provision of feedback about the suggested description and developing samples that help to early-assess the difficulty level
•	Be available to students in case they have questions about the assignments and/or the development environments
•	Adequately and timely respond to students’ email inquiries about the assignment(s)
•	Fair grading of group assignments, and timely reporting of results with explanation to help students understand where they fell short of requirements
•	Attend weekly sync-ups/assessment sessions with the student groups

duties:
The TA will be responsible for helping the course instructor prepare mid-term individual and group project assignments, providing guidance to students with course group projects, uploading course materials, coordinating student access to computing resources when required, and scheduling student presentations.
Projects assignments in this course are related to electric vehicle (EV)  thermal management, EV battery cell characterization, etc.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:

job_title: Data Science Methods and Statistical Learning
department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please apply at: https://ta.mie.utoronto.ca
duties:
This in-person course covers fundamental topics from data science, machine learning, and applied statistics including the use of Python, its data science packages, statistical tools and methods, exploratory data analysis methods, and the process of using data for making inference. The course is structured with both weekly lectures and tutorials/Q&A sessions partly based on the chapters of a publicly available textbook "An Introduction to Statistical Learning With Applications in Python" https://hastie.su.domains/ISLP/ISLP_website.pdf . The students complete eight reading assignments and two data science projects for this course in addition to a midterm assessment and a final exam._x000D_

duties:
The hired course instructor will be responsible for managing the delivery of labs, lectures and tutorials for this course. Lecture-related duties include the preparation of lectures, in-person lecture delivery (4h/week), developing weekly online review quizzes, creation of and grading of term tests and final exams, marks management, holding regularly scheduled weekly office hours, and management of the Quercus course page. Tutorial-related duties include the preparation and distribution of weekly problem sets, quizzes and grading keys, as well as overseeing the grading and marks management by the tutorial TAs. Lab-related duties include distributing supporting materials to the lab TAs, overseeing the delivery of the last two experiments in the course, providing writing instruction to students completing their formal lab reports and overseeing the grading and marks management by the lab TAs.

The ideal candidate will have practical implementation experience of climate change mitigation policies and measures, actions, and plans in the public sector (national, provincial, and municipal governments) and private sector. The Engineering Science Option Seminar supports Engineering Science students transitioning into their major in the third year of study, and encourages them to begin thinking about their goals post-graduation. 

The Assignment Administration Teaching Assistant will be responsible for creating and implementing a participant-matching system to pair students with interested alumni based on information provided by both parties. They will also support students in completing an associated Informational Interview assignment.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

application_procedure: Follow application procedures outlined here: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/about/job-postings/cupe-unit-1/
duties: As part of an English Language Learning (ELL) Initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead TA will work with the ELL Coordinator to support Course Instructors and train regular course TAs in selected courses. The LTA will perform the following duties (remotely in the summer; in person elements of the core classes are meeting in person in the fall/winter): Participation in relevant parts of online WIT (Writing Intensive Teaching) training over the summer; Participate in training throughout the year; Meet in summer with ELL Coordinator and course instructors to plan course assignments and tutorials/labs; Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs (on topics such as responding to and grading assignments, planning tutorial activities related to scholarly reading, etc.) through Fall and Winter terms; Develop and/or adapt resources on language and writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignment guides) for course instructors, TAs, and students; Communicate regularly with course instructors, ELL Coordinator, and others to coordinate activities; Collect data (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, etc.); Document activities (e.g., unit goals, monthly updates, write a final a report about the initiatives impact in the unit, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Previous experience (at least two years' experience as a course TA in EAS's core courses (EAS103H1, EAS105H1, and/or EAS209H1), including leading tutorials); Excellent oral and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with course instructors and TAs; Strong administrative skills, including scheduling meetings and planning, time management, meeting multiple deadlines, and documenting work; Able to prioritize tasks; Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops; Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline; Flexible schedule, able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings

duties: Teaching Assistant will help with course preparation, assessment, and delivery. Preparation duties may involve setting up Quercus pages, lecture content, and assignments. Assesment duties will involve providing feedback on student  assignments - oral presentations, short papers, or scientific articles. Delivery may involve leading in class discussions, or reporting on current trends or research in science communication.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be at least enrolled in the later years of a BA or BASC in  a discipline such as Engineering, IHPST, or Communication Studies.   Must be able to adapt and respond to unexpected classroom situations, express, argue and defend opinions to both students and instructors and demonstrate strong communication skills in oral and written forms. Must have demonstrated experience with the history, theory and practice  of science communcation, either through classes, extracurricular or industry experience  or research.
qualifications_preferred: Experience as a student or TA in the first-year foundation course, Engineering Strategies and Practice, Praxis or any other engineering communication courses, including TEP321,  is desirable.
salery: $47.64 per hour + vacation pay (as of Jan 1, 2023). Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Please submit your application form and resume to clerissa.albores@utoronto.ca. duties:
Attending exam facilitation training prior to the Final Exam period; Be available for in-person, morning exams at UTM on the following dates for 3-4 hour intervals: November 28th, November 30th, December 2nd, December 5th, December 6th, December 8th, December 9th, December 12th, December 13th, December 15th; Picking up exam materials before an exam; Setting up the exam room by distributing question papers and exam materials; Following protocols for both paper-based and computer-based examinations; Working collaboratively with the instructor to best facilitate the exam; Ensuring Faculty policies and procedures on exam administration are followed; Monitoring for academic misconduct (e.g., the use of unauthorized aids), recording incidents and reporting to the instructor when needed; Making announcements to students in the exam room; Collecting student signatures for attendance tracking; Potentially dealing with urgent situations such as students who are unexpectedly sick or fire alarms; Ensuring all exam papers have been submitted and secured; Directing Assistant Invigilators (usually 2-7 per exam across multiple rooms) to carry out protocols with professionalism, integrity and accuracy; You may be called to a meeting after the Final Exam period to discuss any incidents that occurred during exams. You will be paid for this time.

Qualifications
(a)Previous experience as a Teaching Assistant or Sessional Instructional Assistant, for MMPA
(b)Previous experience facilitating in-person exams, for MMPA 
(c) Not currently enrolled in the MMPA Program
(d) Exceptional service and professionalism
(e) Excellent communication and problem-solving skills
(f) Ability to carry out procedures under pressure, using tact and judgement
(g) Ability to effectively direct large groups
